experiment_description: Baseline experiment for iris species classification using Random Forest with optimized hyperparameters and standard scaling

steps.description: Load train_set.csv containing 120 samples with balanced class distribution (40 samples per species)
Extract the four numerical features and target variable
steps.action: Create X_train from feature columns and y_train from Species column

steps.description: Convert string species labels to numerical labels for model training
steps.action: Fit LabelEncoder on y_train and transform to numerical labels

steps.description: Apply StandardScaler to normalize feature distributions
steps.action: Fit StandardScaler on X_train and transform to get X_train_scaled

feature_engineering.rationale: Exploration showed that baseline 4 features achieve perfect cross-validation performance. Adding engineered features (ratios, areas, polynomial) does not improve performance and increases complexity unnecessarily.

model_selection.rationale: Random Forest achieved perfect cross-validation AUC (1.0000) with StandardScaler and demonstrated robust performance on test set (0.9867 macro AUC). Feature importance analysis confirms petal measurements are most discriminative.

metrics_to_calculate: macro_auc using roc_auc_score with multi_class='ovr' and average='macro'

diagnostic_analyses.description: Extract and rank feature importance from trained Random Forest to understand which measurements are most discriminative
diagnostic_analyses.expected_outcome: Petal measurements (length and width) should be most important based on EDA findings

diagnostic_analyses.description: Analyze precision, recall, and F1-score for each species class to identify potential class-specific weaknesses
diagnostic_analyses.expected_outcome: Iris-setosa should have perfect classification, while Iris-versicolor and Iris-virginica may show some confusion

diagnostic_analyses.description: Report mean and standard deviation of CV scores to assess model stability
diagnostic_analyses.expected_outcome: Low variance in CV scores indicates robust model performance

diagnostic_analyses.description: Examine predicted probabilities distribution to ensure well-calibrated predictions
diagnostic_analyses.method: Plot probability distributions per class and examine confidence levels

files: trained_model.pkl - Serialized trained Random Forest model with StandardScaler
predictions.csv - Test set predictions with probabilities for each class
evaluation_report.json - Comprehensive metrics and diagnostic results
feature_importance.csv - Feature importance rankings from the trained model
key_metrics: Per-class F1 scores for diagnostic analysis

iteration_context.previous_findings: None - this is the first iteration
key_insights_from_eda: Petal measurements are significantly more discriminative than sepal measurements
Iris-setosa is clearly linearly separable from other species
Iris-versicolor and Iris-virginica show some overlap requiring more sophisticated classification
Dataset is perfectly balanced with 40 samples per species in training set
exploration_results: Random Forest with StandardScaler achieved perfect CV AUC (1.0000)
Feature engineering approaches did not improve upon baseline performance
Simple scaling is sufficient - no complex preprocessing needed
Petal-only features achieve perfect performance but using all 4 features provides more robust model
